messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: If we want to know where our ability for complex language comes from, we must look at how our brains differ from those of other animals. This is about more than just brain size; it also matters what other functions our brains have and when and why they changed in that way. However, there are very few physical clues, because artefacts left by our ancestors do not show what speech they could produce. One thing we can see in the bones of early humans, though, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had gained the ability to make complex sounds. Before that time, evolutionary biologists, who are scientists that study how living things change over time, can only guess whether early humans used more basic sounds to communicate.
Feedback received: Grade 5/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Compliance. The text was classified as 'B2', which is above the target 'B1' level. While factual integrity and meaning preservation were excellent, the sentence structures are too complex for B1 learners. The text uses long sentences with multiple clauses. For example, the sentence 'Before that time, evolutionary biologists, who are scientists that study how living things change over time, can only guess whether early humans used more basic sounds to communicate' is very long and uses an embedded relative clause, which is a B2-level feature. Suggestion: Break down long, complex sentences into shorter, simpler ones. For instance, define the keyword first: 'Evolutionary biologists are scientists who study how living things change over time.' Then, write the main sentence: 'They can only guess if early humans used more basic sounds to communicate before that time.'

Text saved: We want to know where our ability for complex language comes from. To find out, we must look at how our brains are different from animal brains. It is not only about brain size. It also matters what other functions our brains have. We also need to know when and why they changed. However, there are very few physical clues. Artefacts left by our ancestors do not show what speech they could produce. One thing we can see in the bones of early humans is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had gained the ability to make complex sounds. Evolutionary biologists (scientists who study how living things change over time) can only guess if early humans used more basic sounds to communicate before that time.
Feedback received: Grade 4/10 - FAIL

To reach the B1 level, these should be combined using appropriate connectors. Suggestion: 'It is not only about brain size, because it also matters what other functions our brains have and why they changed over time.' While factual integrity was maintained and the keyword was defined correctly, the text must be revised to include more varied and complex sentence structures to meet the B1 standard.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level B1

Text saved: We want to know where our ability for complex language comes from. So we must look at how our brains differ from those of other animals. It is not only about brain size. It also matters what other functions our brains have. It also matters when they changed. It also matters why they changed. However, there are very few physical clues. Our ancestors left artefacts. These artefacts do not show what speech they could produce. One thing we can see in the bones of early humans is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100 000 years ago humans had gained the ability to make complex sounds. Evolutionary biologists (scientists who study how species change over time) study how living things change over time. They can only guess if early humans used basic sounds to communicate before that time.
Feedback received: Grade 9/10 - PASS

metadata.feedback_text: This is a strong PASS. The output successfully passes all priority checks for factual integrity, meaning preservation, and CEFR compliance. The strategy of breaking down long sentences into shorter ones was effective for achieving B1 clarity. The keyword 'evolutionary biologists' was handled perfectly with a clear parenthetical definition. For improvement, consider the flow in the middle of the text. The repetition of 'It also matters...' makes the text slightly choppy. A more significant issue is the final sentence structure: 'Evolutionary biologists (scientists who study how species change over time) study how living things change over time.' The main clause here is redundant because it repeats information already given in the definition. A more concise version would be: 'Evolutionary biologists (scientists who study how species change over time) can only guess if early humans used basic sounds to communicate before that time.'
